Mark Meadows Resignation Reignites Trump Chief of Staff Rumors
By John Gizzi 
Thursday, 19 December 2019  "Within minutes of the stunning announcement Thursday morning by Rep. Mark Meadows, R.-N.C., that he would not seek re-election in 2020, speculation was sparked that the four-term conservative lawmaker would be the next White House chief of staff. Amid growing reports that President Donald Trump is dissatisfied with his current chief of staff Mick Mulvaney, several sources close to the White House say he would prefer the more activist Meadows — a fierce Trump loyalist and former chairman of the conservative House Freedom Caucus. A builder and developer (like Trump), Meadows, 60, made little secret of his desire to leave Congress and take over the White House staff in January when then-chief of staff John Kelly resigned. The job went instead to Mulvaney, who has served for nearly a year on an "acting" basis while still officially holding the position of director of the Office of Management and Budget. Other close Trump-watchers told Newsmax that it would be unwise for the president to appoint his fourth chief of staff in as many years and that he might be smarter to consider naming Meadows if he is re-elected next year. Others take a different view of Meadows becoming chief of staff. Chris Whipple, author of the best-selling book "The Gatekeepers: How the White House Chiefs of Staff Define Every Presidency," told us: "Without singling anyone out by name, I would simply say the last thing Trump needs is another sycophant as White House chief of staff."
~~~~~~~

https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2019/10/mick-mulvaney-impeachment/600313/ Why Firing Mick Mulvaney Is Riskier Than Keeping Him
President Trump’s third chief of staff seemed destined for the door until impeachment came along. OCTOBER 18, 2019
Mick Mulvaney's job was in danger even before his disastrous press conference yesterday, and his equally disastrous attempt to walk that performance back. The fumble could not have been more poorly timed: According to multiple current and former White House officials, many of whom spoke on the condition of anonymity to relay private conversations, Trump has been steadily souring on Mulvaney for weeks.
. . .
The president has polled confidants about whether Mulvaney is up to the job, blaming him for leaks and negative news coverage, and considering whether he should find someone else to run the West Wing. It might stand to reason, then, that with Trump’s growing frustrations with Mulvaney—coupled with a performance yesterday that could put Trump in greater legal jeopardy than ever before—Mulvaney’s days as acting chief of staff are numbered. Yesterday’s press conference was significant not just for Mulvaney’s revelations about Trump’s dealings with Ukraine. It also laid bare just how key a role Mulvaney has played in those dealings. Mulvaney admitted, for example, that Trump had spoken to him directly about an issue at the heart of Congress’s impeachment inquiry: withholding aid to Ukraine partly because Trump wanted an investigation into a conspiracy theory involving a Democratic National Committee server. Trump was not happy—and neither were his most prominent allies. The shock of Mulvaney’s admission was only compounded by the flippancy with which he delivered it: For those troubled by it, he told reporters, “get over it.” Mulvaney later walked the claim back, but even in the eyes of the president’s closest confidants, the damage was done. For a White House staffer, there is perhaps no worse place to be than in Sean Hannity’s crosshairs, and that’s where Mulvaney found himself yesterday, after undercutting the administration’s talking points on impeachment in a way that not even a Trump-loving Fox News host could spin. Shortly after the press conference, Hannity excoriated the acting chief on his radio show: “What is Mulvaney even talking about?” Hannity scoffed. “I just think he’s dumb, I really do. I don’t even think he knows what he’s talking about. That’s my take on it.” Nevertheless, in the course of combusting the White House’s narrative on impeachment, Mulvaney unwittingly demonstrated why, at this fraught moment in Trump’s presidency, he may be untouchable: Should Trump fire him and leave him aggrieved, Mulvaney could prove a damaging witness in Congress’s impeachment investigation. A former White House official said Trump “will be feeling the pain of having pushed out [former National Security Adviser John] Bolton at a very inopportune time. He won’t make the same mistake with Mulvaney, however frustrated he may be with him. Now, their interests are aligned. They sink or swim together.” It’s a line of thinking that has come to permeate the West Wing, and it marks a significant shift in how Trump is beginning to view his relationship with his staffers. For the past two and a half years, the White House has operated like a radio perpetually set on scan, with Trump sampling staffer after staffer in search of those whose rhythms match his own. Indeed, as Mulvaney told us earlier this year, it’s made for a West Wing whose atmosphere is dictated by one particular maxim: “He could fire any of us tomorrow.” With the backdrop of impeachment, however, some White House staffers could feel more secure in their jobs than even their boss—and that’s perhaps especially true of Mulvaney. As Democrats move forward in their investigation, they’re looking for star witnesses, those officials in Trump’s inner circle who could speak authoritatively as to whether Trump pressured a foreign power to open investigations into both the 2016 election and former Vice President Joe Biden. And should Trump discard an adviser in his preferred manner—hastily announce the news on Twitter, then trash the person’s reputation—he or she may decide to become said star witness.
. . .
Bolton’s uncertain loyalty in this pivotal moment has convinced many of Trump’s allies that, eager as the president may be to oust him, Mulvaney is better kept inside of the White House. According to the current and former White House officials and others close to the president, people have been urging Trump to hold his acting chief in place, telling him that the risk of an aggrieved ex-official on the outside far outweighs any annoyances Trump may have with him. As President Lyndon Johnson famously said about then–FBI Director J. Edgar Hoover, it’s better to keep him inside the tent “pissing out” than the opposite. “The president always fears that people he either gets rid of or resigns will turn out to be a press liability,” one person close to the White House told us. “But, look, if you treat people like crap, you shouldn’t expect loyalty.” According to legal experts, by keeping Mulvaney in place, Trump can make a stronger case that Mulvaney is immune from having to testify about conversations with the president. “It becomes more difficult to control those who are no longer part of the executive branch,” Jonathan Turley, a George Washington University law professor, told us. This is not to say, of course, that Trumpworld was quick to move on from Mulvaney’s disastrous briefing-room appearance. One of the president’s personal lawyers, Jay Sekulow, released a terse statement after Mulvaney’s press conference, saying that Trump’s legal team “was not involved” in the briefing. However, the fact that Mulvaney still holds his job—in spite of the torrent of criticism inside and outside the White House—could underscore just how much impeachment has come to scramble the regular rhythms of this presidency. Gone, perhaps, are the days when Trump would give little thought to axing a senior official. Because while tell-all books come and go—promising a juicy anecdote here, a gossipy passage there—the impeachment inquiry is in motion. Which means the risk of ushering his staff into the arms of Democratic investigators is one that Trump may become less and less inclined to take. There was a curious moment on Wednesday in the Oval Office, when Trump’s opinion of Bolton suddenly seemed to brighten. No longer did Trump want to dwell on his disagreements with Bolton or how Bolton had wrongly supported the Bush administration’s war in Iraq. “I actually got along with him pretty well. It just didn’t work out,” Trump told reporters during a meeting with his Italian counterpart, Sergio Mattarella. It was as though Trump was telegraphing an understanding of the stakes, in this moment, of having his former national security adviser as an enemy. And earlier today, when he brushed off reporters’ questions about Mulvaney’s press conference, saying simply, “I think he clarified it,” Trump seemed to communicate another message of self-awareness: that he, more than ever, needs Mulvaney as a friend.
~~~~~~~

https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/11/us/politics/bolton-mulvaney-impeachment.html?nl=todaysheadlines&emc=edit_th_191112?campaign_id=2&instance_id=13710&segment_id=18714&user_id=0a0c579776f0cfaf13a2bd3672253728&regi_id=286991831112  President Trump’s chief of staff and former national security adviser clashed in court on Monday. . . . when Mick Mulvaney, the acting White House chief of staff, abruptly withdrew his effort to join a lawsuit over impeachment testimony after a sharp collision with his onetime colleague John R. Bolton, the former national security adviser. Mr. Mulvaney retreated only hours after a lawyer for Mr. Bolton and his former deputy, Charles M. Kupperman, went to court arguing that his clients wanted nothing to do with the staff chief because they had vastly different interests. In withdrawing his motion, Mr. Mulvaney indicated that he would now press his own lawsuit to determine whether to comply with a subpoena to testify in the House impeachment inquiry. But it left him at odds with the president, who has ordered his team not to cooperate with the House, an order Mr. Mulvaney has essentially refused to accept as other administration officials have until he receives separate guidance from a judge. Mr. Mulvaney’s lawyers emphasized that he was not trying to oppose Mr. Trump, maintaining that he was actually trying to sue House Democrats, and an administration official who insisted on anonymity said there was “no distance” between the president and his chief of staff. Still, Mr. Mulvaney hired his own lawyer instead of relying on the White House counsel, and he consciously made clear that he was open to testifying if left to his own devices. The situation underscored the longstanding enmity between Mr. Mulvaney and the counsel, Pat A. Cipollone, who have repeatedly been at odds throughout the impeachment inquiry, according to four administration officials briefed on the events. Mr. Mulvaney, who has been left with an “acting” title for more than 10 months and therefore insecure in his position, is said to see Mr. Cipollone as angling for his job as chief of staff. People close to Mr. Cipollone deny that and say he is not interested, although they acknowledged that there were previous discussions with Mr. Trump about such a shift. Hoping to bolster his own place in the White House, Mr. Mulvaney has recommended to Mr. Trump that he hire Mark Paoletta, the general counsel at the Office of Management and Budget, where Mr. Mulvaney is still technically the director, according to people familiar with the maneuvering. Mr. Paoletta would not displace Mr. Cipollone but would give Mr. Mulvaney an ally on the legal team as the impeachment battle plays out. Another person familiar with the latest moves said that Mr. Paoletta was considered, but that West Wing officials decided they were pleased with the hiring of Pam Bondi, a former attorney general of Florida, and Tony Sayegh, a Republican strategist, both of whom began full time this week. The latest personnel struggle echoed an attempt by Mr. Mulvaney several weeks ago to hire former Representative Trey Gowdy, a fellow South Carolina Republican, to join the president’s legal team. Mr. Cipollone and others were said to take issue with the idea, concerned it was an effort by Mr. Mulvaney to run his own legal team. Mr. Cipollone told allies he had no such concerns, but eventually, Mr. Gowdy bowed out, facing an issue with a ban on former House members lobbying Congress. Despite his own tenuous job status, Mr. Mulvaney has privately told associates in recent days that there is no easy way for Mr. Trump to fire him in the midst of the impeachment fight, the implication being that he knows too much about the president’s pressure campaign to force Ukraine to provide incriminating information about Democrats. The court fight between Mr. Mulvaney and Mr. Bolton on Monday brought their long-running feud into the open. Mr. Mulvaney was among those facilitating the Ukraine effort, while Mr. Bolton was among those objecting to it. At one point, according to testimony in the impeachment inquiry, Mr. Bolton declared that he wanted no part of the “drug deal” Mr. Mulvaney was cooking up, as the then national security adviser characterized the pressure campaign. . . .

The filing of the lawsuit changes things dramatically.  He is much less likely to be fired now.   Specifically, there are four possible reasons why he did it:  1)  He felt pangs of  conscious and decided to challenge Trump. 2) He wanted to avoid a possible jail sentence.  3) He wanted to delay the inevitable,   4) Or,  he and Trump want a judicial ruling finding immunity really exists in this context, and they think this is the best way to get it.     The idea that Mulvaney has a conscious is laughable given his history, and Trump would probably have fired him already.  There is little chance he will go to jail, given no one else has and AG Barr will not likely prosecute anyone for refusing to testify.   The lawsuit would delay his testifying only if he planned on eventually obeying the subpoena, but that is not likely.  Trump wants a judicial finding that immunity is not something he and his lawyers just made up.  Actually, it is not, but the press reports suggests the courts have never recognized it.   The best way to have a court recognize immunity would be to 1) have the person with the best justification for it file a lawsuit and 2) present arguments favorable to the president in that lawsuit.  Mulvaney's attempt to intervene in the lawsuit filed by Bolton and Kupperman did just that.  If Mulvaney had succeeded in joining Bolton and Kupperman's lawsuit, it could have changed the nature of the lawsuit entirely.   Bolton at least seems to want to tell his story and may present legal arguments suggesting immunity is  nonsense.   Mulvaney would then have presented legal arguments and authorities  that no one might have presented in his absence.  Mulvaney's lawyers might have been able to tilt the filed toward the president.  Any lawyer wanting to litigate immunity would want to do it with the  person most likely to win--and that is Mulvaney.    Mulvaney is more likely to get the immunity because he is a current, not former, member of the White House staff, unlike Bolton and Kupperman.  He also has information related to the internal workings of the White House.  A White House chief of staff normally spends a lot of time pondering with the president alternative courses of action.  A court will likely feel that a president needs to do this in private so he can freely formulate policy on a vary wide variety of issues.  Some of the things considered could be strictly political and/or some options could be extremely embarrassing if revealed.   Yet, in order to thoroughly evaluate a possible course of action, considering unpopular options may have to be discussed.  Privacy is essential for this to occur. It is kind of like a lawyer's impressions of his client's case--which are never discoverable.   The lawyer needs to know he can discuss his client's case with co-counsel without the opposition knowing what they discussed.    Thus,  Mulvaney should have a much better argument for immunity than the Bolton and Kupperman who are lower down the food chain and may not have had the same contact with the president.   If this is the reason why Mulvaney filed a lawsuit, it would not be the first time.  Paul Manafort after pleading guilty (to additional counts after conviction on some counts agreed to cooperate with Meuller and the grand jury investigating Trump.  Manafort did not cooperate but continued to lie.  He  listened to all the questions I suspected he relayed the questions back to the Trump team.  The sentencing judge said Manafort continued to lie in hopes of getting a pardon. 

President Trump does not fire those who, like Kelly Anne Conway, defend him no matter what.     All Mulvaney's past sins could be forgiven if he won and established immunity as a legal doctrine--making Trump and any other president almost a dictator.  Also, if immunity is found, the courts may find it exists only for current, not former, staff members.  So, I think Mulvaney's chances of staying improved greatly with this lawsuit.    If I am wrong, Mulvaney will be gone very soon.

https://www.cnn.com/2019/09/28/politics/mick-mulvaney-impeachment-inquiry-donald-trump/index.html Acting White House chief of staff Mick Mulvaney is on shaky ground in the wake of a bad week for President Trump, according to multiple sources with knowledge of discussions surrounding the whistleblower fallout. The sources say the President is not upset with Mulvaney for the White House releasing the summary of his July 25 call with Ukraine's leader or the whistleblower complaint because he had been convinced that it was necessary. What Trump and other aides are frustrated with, according to the sources, is that Mulvaney did not have a strategy for defending and explaining the contents of those documents as soon as they were publicly released. One of the sources says it's not just the President, but also widespread frustration in the White House about the lack of a response plan to deal with the fallout after the release of the whistleblower complaint ignited more controversy surrounding the President. The sources say Mulvaney is taking the heat for that. White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham said Saturday in a statement, "This story is manufactured palace intrigue. "The fact is that President Trump and this Administration have done nothing wrong," the statement continued. "Why would we need to implement a strategy to explain the contents of a document we willingly released? Sounds to me like more anonymous troublemakers working to stir the pot for their own selfish reasons." The feeling among some working to contain the controversy is that some aides who pushed for a response felt Mulvaney was getting in the way of allowing it. The frustration over a lack of a response plan poured over into a series of meetings at the White House Friday between the President and top aides, including his personal counsel and White House lawyers, to figure out a strategy moving forward. Sources caution that despite Mulvaney not being in a good place right now, the President may not be eager to fire Mulvaney anytime soon given the amount of tumult, even for a White House used to that. Mulvaney allies are dismissing the notion that he is in trouble. "That literally has no basis in reality," said John Czwartacki, a senior adviser to Mulvaney.
. . . 
The reporting about Mulvaney comes weeks after Trump abruptly fired his then-national security adviser John Bolton. Trump's administration has been marked by a series of exits by high-ranking officials, and the President has already cycled through two White House chiefs of staff. Mulvaney has not lost the "acting" part of his title since stepping into the role after John Kelly left the post at the end of last year. The conservative former South Carolina congressman became the third chief of staff in less than two years to take on the task of running a White House besieged by a drumbeat of investigations. He took over just before Democrats took control of the House of Representatives, and before former special counsel Robert Mueller delivered his report on Russia's interference in the 2016 election. Mulvaney previously represented South Carolina's 5th District in the House of Representatives, where he rose to prominence as a founding member of the Freedom Caucus, a group of hardline conservatives.

Historically, the average tenure of a white house chief of staff is ~18 months, the median is ~21 months. For any other randomly chosen administration, I'd start it at ~19%. Of the 34 that preceded Mulvaney - including "acting" chiefs - 9 lasted less than 1 year, but 4 of those started within a year of the end of a president's term (I chose to include those 4 in the >1year group, it should be noted that there are strong argument to treat them other ways).  Only Gerald Ford (who served 1 term and had the Chief of Staff position vacant for 2.5 years of that time) and George H W Bush (who served one term and brought on his third chief of staff with 150 days remaining in his term) have had multiple Chiefs of Staff that did not last 1 year. As the current administration has already had Reince Priebus ousted after 190 days, it would be unusual but possible to see another <1 year term. Based on that, I'd dial the 19% back to ~15%. Now we come to the reality of the current administration. Pundits and comedians alike discuss the rampant turnover in the first 2 years of this aministration. How true are the jokes? This administration has seen roughly the same turnover of the initial "A Team" in 2.5 years that most recent administrations saw over 4 years. (Brookings has a nice breakdown of this here https://www.brookings.edu/research/tracking-turnover-in-the-trump-administration/ ) That is, of course, not quite the data we need. Mick Mulvaney is not a member of the "A Team" as the Brookings Institute defines it. However, we do see there is real data behind the sense that the current administration is seeing unusually high turnover. We also see 3 cabinet posts with 3 or more departures (of 15 senior level rolls which have 2 or more departures). This administration seems far more likely to see 2 Chiefs of Staff with <1 year tenure than a randomly chosen administration. I would say roughly on the order of twice as likely, arriving at 30%. Recent news suggests the president is unhappy with Mulvaney (one of several examples here https://www.politico.com/story/2019/06/25/trump-mick-mulvaney-white-house-1379594 ); when the current president tires of a senior staff member, they have not been long for their position. Normally, I would boost this by 2x or more (might say as high as 80% if I were in a particularly bullish mood) as 6 months will be a long time for Mulvaney to keep his position in this cabinet while drawing the ire of the president. That said, there are other considerations: Mulvaney repeatedly publicly supported shutting down the government early this year, he has reportedly been using Camp David and loading trips on Air Force One with his preferred staffers, and he is upsetting Republican lawmakers. It could be advantageous to keep him around until the politically appropriate time, cover him in blame and give the appearance of "cleaning house" to draw media attention and excitement from the Democratic primaries in H1 of 2020. Moreover, while brief, the last search for a Chief of staff was very embarrassing for the president with multiple politicians publicly declining the role. The president is not averse to controversy; however, embarrassment may be the driver that keeps him in check. Here I land at only a +5% from the previous 30%, the president's apparent tiring of Mulvaney doesn't yet seem to be strong ire and he will avoid another embarrassing situation if possible. Additionally, as the Politico article above states, Mulvaney has been very hands-off with the president - something I assume the president appreciates. 35% - unlikely, but still well in the realm of possible.

This question asks whether MM will remain as COS for one year. Nine of the 29 CsOS (acting and permanent) have lasted for less than one year (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_House_Chief_of_Staff). The median tenure is just under two years. I'll use 31% as my base rate. DJT has had historically high turnover in his administration, including Cabinet level positions (https://www.npr.org/2018/03/19/594164065/trump-cabinet-turnover-sets-record-going-back-100-years), and senior White House Staff (https://www.npr.org/2018/03/07/591372397/white-house-staff-turnover-was-already-record-setting-then-more-advisers-left). In fact, depending on the metrics it appears to be 2-3 times as high as recent Presidents. I double the odds to 62%. MM is serving in an acting capacity and not a permanent capacity. I believe that this makes political and PR barriers to replacing him low relative to that of a permanent COS. In a typical administration I might weigh that fact as 25% more likely to not finish the year, but with DJT I think it weighs less. He is not as concerned with the fallout, so I only pump it up 15% to 77%.  Since I am jumping in late, five of the twelve months have already passed. MM has largely avoided public drama with DJT, and things appear to be going as smoothly for him as things go for anyone over there. I am dropping the likelihood of MM leaving by 20 % to account for the reduced time remaining, which leaves me at 57%.

Trump has gone through two chiefs (Kelly 557 days and Priebus 154 days) who lasted a total of 711 days -- or an average of 355.5 days.   January 1, 2020 is only 264 days away.  Hence, if Mulvaney lasts the average of his two predecessors, he will only last another (355.5 -117 days already served= )  238.5--about 25 days short.  I did not compute a variance for two chiefs, but it would have been high, and the sample size is small.  Thus, the outside view is less reliable.  I suspect Priebus may not have lasted because he refused or resisted going along with Trump's crazier requests, e.g., announcing Trump had the largest inaugural crowd ever.  Kelly may have lasted so long out of a sense of duty to the country based upon what I read.  He clearly hated the job.   Trump tosses out experienced and qualified staff like old shoes.   It seems like the sleezyer the staffer, the longer they last, e.g.,  Sarah Saunders, Kelly Ann Conway, Steven Miller ,.. need I go on.  The key ingredients seem to be loyalty to Trump, not embarassing Trump and not outshining Trump--unless you are defending him.  Really, unconditional loyalty in the face of the Russian, tax and financial investigations and scandals seems to be the key to longevity.     Mulvaney seems to meet the criteria for staying as stated above.   That is,   See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mick_Mulvaney.   Thus, outside view would probably be about 45 percent chance that he will STAY.  The high variance  and small sample size reduces the probability  to maybe 35 percent.   The inside view would add 35 percent, given the factors listed above.   Yielding a final 70 percent probability of Mulvaney staying.  I realize that I am allowing my dislike of Trump and his administration to influence my position.  So, maybe, I should knock off another 10 percent.  But, then again maybe not.  So I end up with a 30 percent chance of CEASING to be Chief.   (I need to change the number in the estimate box; it was a typo.) I wonder if I have over-stated the inside view.  Again, the outside is less reliable because of the high variance and small sample size.  Moreover, it does seem that it was Trump's original appointees who did not last long.  It also seems a lot of them were government professionals who resisted his nonsense or were chosen just because they were prominent Republicans with strong support in the party but no ties or personal loyalty to Trump.    Trump's subsequent appointments did not suffer from the same bouts of common sense or lack of unconditional loyalty  in the face of his many scandals.  Hence, it took Trump a little while to find the right people for his White House.   Thus, I think giving a lot more weight than unusual to the inside view makes sense.

I started making this forecast by finding the base rate. I used the % of cabinet and cabinet-level positions listed on Wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cabinet_of_the_United_States)  that are no longer filled by their original staff. This came to 52% (I didn't include VP as it's elected). More accurate would have been % retention of officials in these positions but my way saved time. I then made a listed of all the factors I could ascertain from a quick read of articles. These included the two linked in the question information here, and this 
https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/07/us/politics/mulvaney-south-carolina-chief-staff.html
A search through articles written about Mulvaney in the NYT over the last month yielded little, so I took that to mean few developments since his appointment on how he's doing. These factors included:
-He has lasted at the OMB for a long time, indicating his ability to work within the administration
-But there are some indications he's interested in other positions, for example at USC (though this evidence doesn't seem too strong)
-Past Chiefs of Staff have lasted 6 months and 18 months
-He is listed as acting instead of permanent, even though the role does not require Congressional approval. This could indicate hedging on Trump's part in case it doesn't work out, or could have been driven by Mulvaney's desire to return to OMB (he has not given up his position). However, as written in the Politico article, he has brought his own staff in, indicating some permanence. Balancing the above factors, I set my forecast at 40%. I did a quick Fermi process to make sure I hadn't missed anything essential, and also played around with scope sensitivity. I.e. if the date was changed to 6 months from now, I would drop my forecast to 30%. However, if it was pushed out to the 2020 Presidential election, I would up it to 65%. Based on that I felt comfortable staying at 40%.  Finally I had a quick look at others' forecasts but found no additional evidence at this time. Will continue to monitor what others write and update as needed.
